byline: Interview by Perrine Mouterde (Belem (Brazil), special correspondent) and Audrey Garric (Belem (Brazil), special correspondent)

byline: By Christophe Châtelot and Claire Gatinois (Libreville (Gabon), special correspondent)
subhed: After the G20 summit in Johannesburg, the French president made a stop in Libreville on Sunday. His warm welcome from Brice Oligui Nguema stood in sharp contrast to the anti-French sentiment spreading across the continent.

title: The French far right and the 'enemies within'
subhed: While far-right leaders Marine Le Pen and Jordan Bardella claim they have no ideology and are, instead, solely guided by 'common sense,' racist and identitarian currents are still represented in their inner circles, analyzes Le Monde columnist Philippe Bernard.

title: Victor Hugo's interior architecture on display in Paris
subhed: The Maison de Victor Hugo on Place des Vosges unveils a lesser-known side of the writer's life with 'Hugo the decorator,' an exhibition that reveals the creativity he poured into designing his own homes.

title: 'I told him about my day in real time': The couples who can't stop texting on WhatsApp
subhed: While couples in France exchange an average of nine text messages a day, some go far beyond, updating their partner in real time about every event in their day-to-day lives. Is this constant connection a sign of profound intimacy, or a need for control?

title: François Hollande: 'Trump's plan reduces Europe's role to a besieged bystander'
byline: Interview by Ariane Chemin and Thomas Wieder
subhed: In an interview with Le Monde, the former French president argued that 'for Trump, our continent is finished, it no longer counts,' and warned that if Zelensky 'falls, it is our own security that will be compromised. Sooner or later, we too will fall.'

title: Nicolas Guillou, French ICC judge sanctioned by the US: 'You are effectively blacklisted by much of the world's banking system'
byline: Interview by Stéphanie Maupas (The Hague (Netherlands) correspondent)
subhed: Six judges and three prosecutors at the International Criminal Court have been sanctioned by the Trump administration. In an interview with Le Monde, Guillou discusses the impact of these measures on his work and daily life.
